projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DECLARATION OF THE MOST CHRISTIAN KING, LOVIS THE XIIIth. King of FRANCE and NAVARRE. DECLARING The Rea≈øons wherefore His MAJESTY hath prohibited all Trade with ENGLAND.
ALSO That He hath given Commi≈ø≈øion to rai≈øe an Army for the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the KING of ENGLAND.

div.head: A DECLARATION of the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, LOVIS the XIII. KING of FRANCE, and NAVARRE.
div.p:
WHereas about eight yeares ≈øince, a party of tumultuous and di≈øcontented per≈øons, abu≈øing the name and priviledge of Parliament, by fair and ≈øpecious pretences, and the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the riotous City of London, drew the Subjects of England into a mo≈øt violent and bloody Rebellion again≈øt their naturall Leige Lord, our deare and Royall Uncle, Charles the Fir≈øt, King of Great Britaine and Ireland, of mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed and pious memory, which they carryed on with implacable hatred, and indefatigable devili≈øh policies, pur≈øuing all that did oppo≈øe them with blood and rapine, and wading up to the ankles and neck, through a whole red Sea of humane and Country bloud, to the accompli≈øhment of their execrable and prodigious de≈øignes: Which having fully compa≈ø≈øed, by getting His Maje≈øties Sacred Per≈øon into their power; after a mo≈øt inhumane manner they hurry him from one Pri≈øon to another, continually perplexing him with amphibolous Propo≈øitions, ≈øuch as neither in con≈øcience became a Chri≈øtian, nor in honour a King to grant. At length with Ki≈ø≈øes and All-hailes in the fore-front of their Trea≈øon, they invite His Maje≈øty to a Per≈øonall Treaty; who to manife≈øt his pa≈ø≈øionate de≈øire to peace, ≈øpread His Royall Selfe into acts of Grace and Favour; going beyond all His Predece≈ø≈øors in munificent Conce≈ø≈øions: Yet even when he had yeelded beyond their hope and expectation, and ≈øurrendred His mo≈øt indi≈øputable Rights and Prerogatives into their hands: with malice as inexorable as the grave, deep and bottomle≈ø≈øe as hell, they abruptly break off, and by force of Armes drag him to the Bar; where Va≈ø≈øals took upon them to judge
their Soveraigne, and call him to an accompt, who owed an accompt to none but God alone, and having Bla≈øphemou≈øly upbrayded him with the unju≈øt infamies of Tyrant, Traytour, and Murderer; and ≈øufficiently ≈øported them≈øelves with ≈øcorne and contempt, after a ≈ømall intervall of time, in Triumph they convey him to the Scaffold, which in aggravation of his ≈øorrow, they had prepared at the entrance into his Royall Pallace, where in the ≈øight of his Subjects they committed a mo≈øt Barbarous A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øination upon his Sacred Per≈øon, by ≈øevering his Royall Head from his Body, by the hands of the Common Hang-man; a prodition without a match, and ≈øuch as hath filled even the very Souls of Heathens with horrour and amazement: For it was the mo≈øt nefarious, facinorous, flagitious and incogitable act of Per≈øons neither generous, for there was no drop of ingenious bloud in them; Nor men, for they were for≈øaken of humanity, and had lo≈øt the Bowels of manly compa≈ø≈øion; Nor doggs, unle≈ø≈øe of the Brood of Cerberus; nor Tygers, nor Panthers, nor ravening Woolves, nor Sheebeares, nor any thing but the mo≈øt unnaturall, ≈øtrange, very incarnated and tran≈øanimated Devils, that ever u≈øurpt humane ≈øhape, to the vexatious torment and de≈øtruction of mankind: Nor have the≈øe ≈øponges of bloud yet ≈øuckt their fill, but with implacable Malice they yet pur≈øue his Royall I≈ø≈øue, and by force of Armes withhold from them their Indubitate and ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Right, and have ≈øolemnly Proclaimed them Traytours in the chiefe ≈øtreets of that Kingdomes Metropolis, and all other Cities and Corporations, and that it ≈øhall be lawfull for any man to kill them, wherever they ≈øhall meet them within the limits of tho≈øe Territories as Spies and Enemies to the Common-wealth. And they have further declared and Proclaimed, That they will for ever aboli≈øh all Kingly-government, in England and Ireland, as chargable, unnece≈ø≈øary and Tyrannicall, and in ≈øtead thereof will e≈øtabli≈øh an eternall Anarchy, (which they call
a Common-wealth) perpetually en≈ølaving the mi≈øerable people of tho≈øe Kingdomes, to the Tyrannicall wills of them and their Po≈øterity; and having broken the Diadems of State, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of the Regalia, are now by way of ≈øale, ≈øharing all the Lands and Revenues of the Crowne, with the appurtenances among them≈øelves and their Favourits; Thus are they mounted to tran≈øcendents, not to be placed in the cla≈ø≈øes or Rankes of hitherto experienced or practi≈øed wickedne≈ø≈øe; So that if all the Records and Chronicles ancient and Moderne, Divine & prophane, were throughly ≈øearcht by the mo≈øt ≈øcrutinous eye, and all black and dire machinations, plots and con≈øpiracies, either contrived or acted by Rebells and Traytours, again≈øt their Princes, were arithmatically ca≈øt up, here would be found the ≈øumma Totalis, Rebellion and Trea≈øon, being now brought to the fulne≈ø≈øe of perfection:

Nor are the≈øe Fedifragones, mi≈øcreants contented to imbrue, and bathe their hands in the Kings bloud, but they per≈øecute all his relations; inriching them≈øelves in the ruine of his illu≈øtrious Queen: inforcibly withholding from her that Dowry which the King and his Councell, in con≈øideration of a large and va≈øt Summe of Money, alloted for her maintenance: Whereby they have broak the ancient league between the Kingdomes, and given us faire occa≈øion in ho≈øtile manner, with our Armies of Hor≈øe, and Foot, to invade that Kingdome; Nor can we conceal our deepe ≈øence and ju≈øt indignation, at tho≈øe gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øcandalous obloquies, which they daily ca≈øt upon the per≈øon and reputation of our deare Aunt, the Queen Dowager, by their libellous Pamphlets, tho≈øe Me≈ø≈øengers of their Malice, which like the plagues of Aegypt reduplicated and multiplied, they daily ≈øend forth, by which Aegypticall flyes, they endeavour, what in them lyeth, to cau≈øe the ≈øweet oyntment of her pretious name to ≈øtinke upon the face of the Earth; although her unparralelled vertues are ≈øo candid
and general, that ≈øhe may without flattery be ≈øtiled, The Paragon of Queens, the Glory and miracle of her Sex, who≈øe Honour and injuries, we are bound by the bonds of nature, and affinity, to vindicate and revenge.

And that they might macerate the whole world in bloud, and ≈øet all Chri≈øtian Kingdomes into flames and combu≈øtion, they have di≈øpacht their Incendiaries, like Locu≈øts into all parts of Chri≈øtendome, who by ≈øubdolous and ≈ølie in≈øinuations and pretences of popular Liberty, and freedom from Monarchicall Tyranny, endeavour to carck the bonds of protection and fealty betweene Kings and their Subjects, as they have lately done in this our Kingdome, whereby Trumpeting ≈øedition & Rebellion in the ears of our people, they lately ≈øtirred them up to mutinies and in≈øurrections to the apparent hazard of our Royall per≈øon, Crowne and Dignities, which are now by Gods goodne≈ø≈øe appea≈øed and allayed; by which policy of dividing Kings and their Subjects throughout Chri≈øtendome, they hope to immerge all po≈ø≈øibility of our ayde and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in re≈øtoring their pre≈øent Soveraigne, and e≈øtabli≈øh their hermaphroditicall Government with greater Security.

Having therefore upon very ju≈øt grounds both of Con≈øcience and rea≈øon, taken the≈øe premi≈øes into our Princely con≈øideration, we have thought good, by the Nature and deliberate advice and con≈øent of the mo≈øt illu≈øtrious Lady the Queen Regent our Royall Mother, and of the Princes, Prelats and Parliaments of our Kingdome, to ≈øtop and forbid all trade and commerce between the Subjects of our Kingdom and that Rebellious Nation; till they ≈øhall return to their due obedience to their Soveraigne; and by our Royall Proclamation which we have cau≈øed to be publi≈øhed in all our Cities and Towns Corporate, within this our Kingdome of France, &c. We have ≈øtrictly prohibited all Engli≈øh Wool and woollen Cloth, or any other commodities to be brought into this Kingdome, and we have
thereby Commanded all Sheriffs and Mayors, Balliffs and ≈øubordinate Officers to make diligent ≈øearch in all Cities, Towns, and Ports within their ≈øeverall Juri≈ødictions, and to ≈øeize upon and confi≈øcate to our u≈øe, all ≈øuch prohibited goods as they ≈øhall at any time hereafter finde in any part of our Dominions, and who≈øoever ≈øhall conceale any ≈øuch prohibited goods ≈øo in their cu≈øtody, and not di≈øcover them to the chief Magi≈øtrate, or ≈øome other ≈øubordinate Officer in the City, Towne or Port, where they dwell within the compa≈ø≈øe of four and twenty hours, ≈øhall forfeit their E≈øtates, and for the fir≈øt fault, ≈øuffer one Years Impri≈øonment; for the ≈øecond, five Years; and for the Third, perpetuall Impri≈øonment without bayle or mainpri≈øe. And we have further by our ≈øaid Proclamation commanded, that no Merchant or other Subject of our Kingdome, doc export or ≈øuffer to be exported by any Engli≈øh Merchant or others, any Corn, Wine, Oyle, Skins, Nuts, Che≈ønuts, Beef, Pork, or any other Merchandi≈øes into that Kingdome of England: and who≈øoever ≈øhall be found offending herein, ≈øhall incur the penalty of High Trea≈øon. And we have further commanded all Engli≈øhmen, of what degree or quality ≈øoever, not warranted and protected by the King of England, or not naturalized Den zons of this Kingdom, to depart this Kingdome by the 18 of October, next en≈øuing the Date of that our ≈øaid Proclamation; and that no Engli≈øhman what≈øoever not protected or naturalized as afore≈øaid doe pre≈øume to remaine in any part of our Dominions, upon paine of being executed, as Spies, Enemies and Traytours, to this our Kingdome: And it ≈øhall be High Trea≈øon for any Subject of this our Kingdome, to conceal or harbour within their Hou≈øes any Engli≈øhman, not protected and naturalized as afore≈øaid, and not di≈øcover the ≈øaid per≈øon to ≈øome Magi≈øtrate or Ju≈øtice of Peace within four and twenty Houres.

And conceiving our ≈øelves bound both as a Chri≈øtian and a King, by the bonds of Religion and Nature, and the
long continued League between the Kingdomes, to revenge the barbarous murder of the late King of England, of glorious memory, to repaire the injuries of our Royall Aunt, his Queen Dowager, and to re≈øtore King Charls the Second our Co≈øin, to the Thrones of his Kingdomes, and ≈øubdue his People to his obedience, we have I≈ø≈øued forth our Royall Commi≈ø≈øion under the greate Seale of our Kingdome, whereby we have authorized our Right tru≈øty and welbeloved Co≈øin the Count of Saint Paul, to rai≈øe eight Regiments of Hor≈øe, and twelve of Foot, each hor≈øe Regiment to con≈øi≈øt of eight hundred, and the Foot of a thou≈øand; and of our owne Free will and princely grace, we are plea≈øed to advance two yeares pay out of our Royall trea≈øury: and to furni≈øh the ≈øaid Count of Saint Paul, with a traine of Artillery, and all other nece≈ø≈øaries for martiall imployment; and have ≈øtreightly commanded the ≈øaid Count and all other Officers, and Souldiers of that Army, faithfully and obediently to ob≈øerve all ≈øuch commands, as they ≈øhall from time to time receive from our mo≈øt intirely beloved Co≈øin the King of England: and that they be ready to enter any part his Maje≈øties Dominions, as ≈øhall be thought mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary by the ≈øaid King and his Councell, and there to joyne with any of his Maje≈øties Armies, and to fight with, kill and ≈ølay all that they ≈øhall finde in Rebellion again≈øt his ≈øaid Maje≈øty: And fora≈ømuch as all Chri≈øtian Kings are concerned herein, we have thought good to publi≈øh this our Declaration, which we have cau≈øed to be tran≈ølated into all Languages, that all the Kings and Princes of Chri≈øtendome may take notice of our proceedings, and after our example, may contribute their utmo≈øt power and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance for the re≈øtoring that injured King to his Dominions, and reducing his Subjects to his obedience.

closer.dateline:
Given at our Court at Paris,
September 2d. 1649.
